content.question: Permanent bar magnets <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are arranged as shown in the top view diagram. Magnet <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is fixed in place with its south pole on the right and north pole on the left. Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is free to rotate about a fixed vertical axis through its center and is initially oriented with its south pole at the top and the north pole on the bottom. Which of the following best describes whether or not Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will rotate and provides the correct justification?

choices.label: Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will not rotate because the forces exerted on the two poles of Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> by the magnetic field created by Magnet <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> point in opposite directions and the torques due to those forces about the axis will cancel

Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will not rotate because Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is aligned with the magnetic field created by Magnet <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> in the orientation shown.

Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will initially rotate clockwise because Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will tend to align with the magnetic field produced by Magnet <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>

Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will initially rotate clockwise because the force exerted on the north pole of Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> by the magnetic field created by Magnet <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is greater in magnitude than the corresponding force exerted on the south pole of Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> in the arrangement shown.

content.answer: Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will initially rotate clockwise because Magnet <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> will tend to align with the magnetic field produced by Magnet <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>
